Award.AwardTitle: Full-Scale Development: STEM Guides: Building Coherent Infrastructure in Rural Communities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This full-scale project in Maine proposes to derive and develop an educational model for informal science learning in rural areas where ISE venues are non-existent. Should the project be successful, it could serve as a model for other rural areas in the Nation. The target group is youth 10-18 years of age and the content of the endeavor will vary based on the locality. Partners include the Maine Mathematics and Science Alliance; 4-H; Cornerstones of Science libraries; the University of Maine, EDC for evaluation; and local industries.

The project will divide the state into small areas that will be designated as mini-networks. Each mini-network will have more than 1000 eligible students, a network leader, STEM guides, and volunteers. The geographic area will be small so that face-to-face interactions will be facile. Each site mini-network) will derive its own emphases depending on local expertise and industries.

Rural education is an issue in this country that needs solutions for both its youth education as well as its public education. Often these regions are underserved in many ways, including formal education and economic opportunities, leading to a vicious spiral for residents. So, this project will essentially be a pilot project to work out the issues for a broader implementation across the country. Several thousand youths will be impacted across the state. Exposure to the informal STEM learning should be reflected in enhancement of the general knowledge base and academic improvement among the 10-18 year old population, the communities, and the formal education sector.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project explored a new model for supporting informal (out-of-school) STEM learning, especially in rural places where many young people and families may not be aware of all the STEM-related opportunities available to them. Such opportunities might include access to extensive natural resources as well as organizations and programs such as libraries, science clubs, summer camps, afterschool programs such as 4-H, and many online resources. Instead of relying on teachers or parents to occasionally help their own children to find such STEM opportunities, we hired well-respected adults from rural communities and supported them to reach a much larger number of youth throughout the community with connections to STEM learning opportunities that matched their particular interests and skills. We called these new professionals ?STEM Guides? because they guided youth to find and explore available STEM opportunities and resources.

Over the five years of the project and across the five STEM Hubs, STEM Guides documented (through activity logs and/or interviews) a total of 6,484 STEM connections with 1,768 individual youth meeting our demographic profile of 10-18 years of age. On average, these youth were each helped to connect to 3.7 STEM opportunities.

Our research showed that the STEM Guides were committed and greatly enjoyed their work, finding the greatest rewards in watching the youth develop their STEM interests over time, and being able to contribute to their learning trajectories. However, being a STEM Guide was much more challenging than we had expected. The role required many different capabilities, including: STEM knowledge and advocacy, community credibility, flexibility, easy access and rapport with many youth, ability to energize and coordinate local STEM organizations, and an entrepreneurial approach to cross-pollinating STEM-related events and organizations in service of a broad vision of STEM learning. Another ubiquitous challenge in the rural communities we studied was lack of public transportation, which constrained youth ability to participate even in local STEM events; unfortunately liability issues limited the degree to which STEM Guides could drive youth to events themselves.

In terms of sustainability, we believe this kind of STEM-connection role might be taken on by someone who is already salaried and has regular access to youth, such as a teacher or youth development professional. It would, however, take a significant change in mindset for most educators to shift from allegiance to one organization or learning setting, toward a more neutral role as a responsive ?broker? of STEM experiences.

As an additional phase of the project, some STEM Guides coordinated local STEM resources on the specific topic of Emergency Response Technology (ERT), a field that is quickly evolving technological strategies for understanding and responding to disasters. The STEM Guides used the formats of local internships and Teen Science Caf?s to allow youth to interact with firefighters, police, drone pilots, communication experts, and others. Over the course of a year,  more than 500 teens participated in Teen Science Cafe's at 18 sites in 11 states across the country on disasters ranging from hurricanes and flooding to wildfires and avalanches. Our research showed that teens want to know about the vital roles they can play by learning to use technology in the face of natural disasters, and currently know little about the uses of technology in mitigating or responding to them. Overall, this part of the project showed that it is possible to empower youth to become involved, shape their futures, and care for their communities in the face of disasters.
